FORMATION OF TOBACCO SPECIFIC NITROSAMINES
IN FLUE CURED TOBACCO
David_MPeele_ Marvin G_
Riddick, and Mike €
Edwards, R.J. Reynolds
Tobacco Company_
Avoca Division, Merry
Jill; NC_
27957; and Jeff S. Gentry
ard Timothy B.
Nestcr_
R_
J, Reynolds Tobacco Company, Wnston-Salem;
NC;
27102.
Summary
Nitrosation of naturally occurring tobacco a'kaloids is commonly accepled as the
mechanism of tobacco specific nitrosamine (TSNA) fcmation in tobacco. As
minimal-to-no TSNA are present in green tobacco,
TSNA formation and
accumulation are generally considered to occur during curing
Most recent
hypotheses
on mizrobial reduction of nitrate to nitrite and 0*her oxides of
nitrogen (NO, compounds) that react with tobacco alkalcids to form TSNA during
curing_
This natural microbial process remains the prevalent hypothesis for
TSNA formation in cured burley tobacco.
However_
a second mechanisin for the
formation of TSNA, indepencent of microbial activity. is presented in (his work on
flue-cured tobacco.
It is common practice to fluc-cure Virginia or b'onde tobacco in bulk bams tnat
incorporate forced air ventilation and temperature control,
Modern bulk barns
generally use liquid propane gas (LPG} with direct-fired burners that exhaust
combustion gases directly into
barn where the tcbacco is exposed t0 those
combus=
gases_
Our Studies indicate that LPG combustion by-products,
namely NO_
(in the exhaust strean of direct fired, ilue-cured bams) react with
naturally 0.
ccurring tobacco alkaloids to form TSNA
Heat exchange curing
methods
preclude exposure of the
tobacco to combustion gases and by-
products, thereby eliminating this significant source of TSNA fomation, without
degrading leaf quality or smoking character _
Research findings irom
1993 and
S99 will be presented to demonstrate the significance of direct-fired
J5 3
source of TSNA formation in fue-curcd tobacco_
Introduction
For decades, nitrosamines have been a focus 0f considerable research for
vhence references abound in the scientific Iterature
The presence of
nilrosamines in cigarette smoke and their possible role in tobacco
carcinogcnesis wcre first postulated in the scientific literature in 1962.
Extensive research by many investigators since the 1970's reported the
presence of as riany as thirty-five (35) nitrosamines in cigarelte smoke.
subset cf those nitrosamines was considcred tc be specific to tobacco, resulting

jon
